page.title: International reactions to the 2011 Egyptian revolution

rev.diff:
Line 22: Line 22:
}}</ref> On 6 February, protesters in Cairo's Tahrir Square accused Iran of interfering in Egyptian affairs.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.almasryalyoum.com/en/news/thousands-flock-tahrir-honor-protests-martyrs |title=Thousands flock to Tahrir to honor protests' martyrs | Al-Masry Al-Youm: Today's News from Egypt |publisher=Al-Masry Al-Youm |date= |accessdate=8 February 2011}}</ref>
}}</ref> On 6 February, protesters in Cairo's Tahrir Square accused Iran of interfering in Egyptian affairs.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.almasryalyoum.com/en/news/thousands-flock-tahrir-honor-protests-martyrs |title=Thousands flock to Tahrir to honor protests' martyrs | Al-Masry Al-Youm: Today's News from Egypt |publisher=Al-Masry Al-Youm |date= |accessdate=8 February 2011}}</ref>
*: [[Foreign Affairs Minister of Iran|Iranian Foreign Minister]] [[Ali Akbar Salehi]] hoped that the Egyptians' "high aims, national demands and resurrection of their glory could be achieved in the very near future." [[Ministry of Foreign Affairs (Iran)|Iranian Ministry of Foreign Affairs]] spokesman [[Ramin Mehmanparast]] called on Egypt to "abide by the rightful demands of the nation."<ref>{{cite news |author=[[Staff writer]]|title=Egypt Protests Draw Mixed Reaction in Region|url=http://edition.cnn.com/2011/WORLD/meast/01/29/egypt.middle.east.reaction/|work=[[CNN]]|date=29 January 2011 |accessdate=31 January 2011}}</ref> There were "solidarity" protests outside the Egyptian interests section.{{clarify|date=January 2011}}<!--which embassy?-->
*: [[Foreign Affairs Minister of Iran|Iranian Foreign Minister]] [[Ali Akbar Salehi]] hoped that the Egyptians' "high aims, national demands and resurrection of their glory could be achieved in the very near future." [[Ministry of Foreign Affairs (Iran)|Iranian Ministry of Foreign Affairs]] spokesman [[Ramin Mehmanparast]] called on Egypt to "abide by the rightful demands of the nation."<ref>{{cite news |author=[[Staff writer]]|title=Egypt Protests Draw Mixed Reaction in Region|url=http://edition.cnn.com/2011/WORLD/meast/01/29/egypt.middle.east.reaction/|work=[[CNN]]|date=29 January 2011 |accessdate=31 January 2011}}</ref> There were "solidarity" protests outside the Egyptian interests section.{{clarify|date=January 2011}}<!--which embassy?-->
â
*: [[Islamic Consultative Assembly (Iran)|Iranian parliament speaker]] [[Ali Larijani]] said, "The voice of the brave people of Egypt is the voice of revolution. The start of this revolution has astonished the despotic regimes of the region. The parliament supports the uprising of the Tunisian and Egyptian people." He described the protests as "the revolution of the noble."<ref>http://www.pakistantoday.com.pk/2011/01/iran-backs-egypts-revolution-of-the-noble/</ref> Iran backed the protests. Parliament speaker [[Ali Larijani]] called the uprising the "revolution of the noble". He compared Western reaction to the protests with their reaction to the 1979 [[Islamic Revolution]].<ref>{{cite news|author=[[Staff writer]]|title=Iran Backs Egypt's 'Revolution of the Noble'|publisher=''[[Agence France-Presse]]'' (via ''[[The Times of India]]'')|url=http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/world/middle-east/Iran-backs-Egypts-revolution-of-the-noble/articleshow/7392036.cms|date=30 January 2011|accessdate=31 January 2011}}</ref>
+
*: [[Islamic Consultative Assembly (Iran)|Iranian parliament speaker]] [[Ali Larijani]] said, "The voice of the brave people of Egypt is the voice of revolution. The start of this revolution has astonished the despotic regimes of the region. The parliament supports the uprising of the Tunisian and Egyptian people." He described the protests as "the revolution of the noble."<ref>{{cite web|author=Name * |url=http://www.pakistantoday.com.pk/2011/01/iran-backs-egypts-revolution-of-the-noble/ |title=Iran backs Egypt's 'revolution of the noble' | Pakistan Today | Latest news, Breaking news, Pakistan News, World news, business, sport and multimedia |publisher=Pakistan Today |date=2011-01-30 |accessdate=2011-04-27}}</ref> Iran backed the protests. Parliament speaker [[Ali Larijani]] called the uprising the "revolution of the noble". He compared Western reaction to the protests with their reaction to the 1979 [[Islamic Revolution]].<ref>{{cite news|author=[[Staff writer]]|title=Iran Backs Egypt's 'Revolution of the Noble'|publisher=''[[Agence France-Presse]]'' (via ''[[The Times of India]]'')|url=http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/world/middle-east/Iran-backs-Egypts-revolution-of-the-noble/articleshow/7392036.cms|date=30 January 2011|accessdate=31 January 2011}}</ref>
** [[Mir Hossein Mousavi]] and [[Mehdi Karroubi]], former presidential candidates and the leaders of the [[Iranian Green Movement|Green Movement]], released a statement from their virtual [[house arrest]] in Tehran, assuring the Egyptians, "No power can suppress the people's will and demand. Sooner or later, autocratic and tyrant power[s] are sentenced to vanish."<ref name="Khamenei"/>
** [[Mir Hossein Mousavi]] and [[Mehdi Karroubi]], former presidential candidates and the leaders of the [[Iranian Green Movement|Green Movement]], released a statement from their virtual [[house arrest]] in Tehran, assuring the Egyptians, "No power can suppress the people's will and demand. Sooner or later, autocratic and tyrant power[s] are sentenced to vanish."<ref name="Khamenei"/>
* {{flag|Iraq}} â Prime Minister [[Nouri al-Maliki]] stated, "The people have the right to express what they want without being persecuted... One of the characteristics of a lack of democracy is when a leader rules for 30 or 40 years. It is a difficult issue for people, it is intolerable and change is necessary."<ref>{{cite news
* {{flag|Iraq}} â Prime Minister [[Nouri al-Maliki]] stated, "The people have the right to express what they want without being persecuted... One of the characteristics of a lack of democracy is when a leader rules for 30 or 40 years. It is a difficult issue for people, it is intolerable and change is necessary."<ref>{{cite news
Line 33: Line 33:
* {{flag|Israel}} â President [[Shimon Peres]] said Mubarak's "contribution to peace will never be forgotten. I thank him for saving many people's lives by preventing war. The biggest problem isn't changing the government but changing the face of a country as poor as Egypt." He added concerns about the Muslim Brotherhood: "Elections in Egypt are dangerous. Should the Muslim Brotherhood be elected they will not bring peace. Democracy without peace is not a democracy. We fear there will be a change in government without a change in the circumstances which led to this state."<ref>Efraim, Omri (5 February 2011). [http://www.ynetnews.com/articles/0,7340,L-4024283,00.html "Peres Praises Mubarak for His Contribution to Peace â In Jerusalem Conference President thanks His Egyptian Counterpart for 'Saving Many People's Lives by Preventing War'; Expresses Concern over Possibility of Muslim Brotherhood's Rise to Power"]. ''[[Ynetnews]]''. Retrieved 6 February 2011.</ref>
* {{flag|Israel}} â President [[Shimon Peres]] said Mubarak's "contribution to peace will never be forgotten. I thank him for saving many people's lives by preventing war. The biggest problem isn't changing the government but changing the face of a country as poor as Egypt." He added concerns about the Muslim Brotherhood: "Elections in Egypt are dangerous. Should the Muslim Brotherhood be elected they will not bring peace. Democracy without peace is not a democracy. We fear there will be a change in government without a change in the circumstances which led to this state."<ref>Efraim, Omri (5 February 2011). [http://www.ynetnews.com/articles/0,7340,L-4024283,00.html "Peres Praises Mubarak for His Contribution to Peace â In Jerusalem Conference President thanks His Egyptian Counterpart for 'Saving Many People's Lives by Preventing War'; Expresses Concern over Possibility of Muslim Brotherhood's Rise to Power"]. ''[[Ynetnews]]''. Retrieved 6 February 2011.</ref>
*: [[Prime Minister of Israel|Israeli Prime Minister]] [[Benjamin Netanyahu]] and the Israeli Foreign Ministry announced on 28 January that they are keeping a close track of the situation in neighbouring Egypt, but are refraining from taking a political stance. Ministers were told to refrain from commenting<ref name="time">Vick, Karl (30 January 2011). [http://www.time.com/time/world/article/0,8599,2045166,00.html "As Egypt's Crisis Grows, So Do the Anxieties in Israel"]. ''[[Time (magazine)|Time]]''. Retrieved 2 February 2011.</ref> due to the sensitive nature of [[Egypt-Israel relations|relations]].
*: [[Prime Minister of Israel|Israeli Prime Minister]] [[Benjamin Netanyahu]] and the Israeli Foreign Ministry announced on 28 January that they are keeping a close track of the situation in neighbouring Egypt, but are refraining from taking a political stance. Ministers were told to refrain from commenting<ref name="time">Vick, Karl (30 January 2011). [http://www.time.com/time/world/article/0,8599,2045166,00.html "As Egypt's Crisis Grows, So Do the Anxieties in Israel"]. ''[[Time (magazine)|Time]]''. Retrieved 2 February 2011.</ref> due to the sensitive nature of [[Egypt-Israel relations|relations]].
â
*: Foreign Minister [[Avigdor Lieberman]] told European diplomats at the [[Knesset]] that the root cause of the unrest was internal problems. "Whoever thinks that the Palestinian-Israeli conflict is part of the problems in the Middle East is trying to escape reality. [The] big picture of the Middle East shows that major points of contention stem from challenges and confrontations within Islamic society. The Arab world is becoming increasingly weakened. At the end of the day, it is clear to everyone, even to the [[Palestinian Authority]], that the greatest danger they are facing is not Zionism, but rather Hamas and Jihad."<ref>{{cite web|last=Lis |first=Jonathan |url=http://www.haaretz.com/news/diplomacy-defense/lieberman-mideast-uprisings-show-the-arab-world-is-weakening-1.341859 |title=Lieberman: Mideast uprisings show the Arab world is weakening â Haaretz Daily Newspaper | Israel News |publisher=Haaretz.com |date=7 November 2010 |accessdate=11 February 2011}}</ref> During the early days of the protests, the Foreign Ministry was receiving updates every few hours and Lieberman was in close contact with the Israeli ambassador to Egypt, Yitzhak Levanon.<ref>{{cite web|author=Ravid, Barak (with news agencies)|url=http://www.haaretz.com/news/diplomacy-defense/pm-netanyahu-israel-will-monitor-but-not-comment-on-egypt-protests-1.339895 |title=PM Netanyahu: Israel Will Monitor But Not Comment on Egypt Protests â The Foreign Ministry Is Conducting Status Updates on Egypt Every Couple of Hours and Foreign Minister Avigdor Lieberman Has Been Maintaining Close Contact with Israel's Ambassador to Egypt|work=[[Haaretz]] |date=29 January 2011 |accessdate=31 January 2011}}</ref> The Ministry was concerned over "substantial" changes in the regime.<ref name="israel evacuation">{{cite web|author=[[Staff writer]]|url=http://www.qassam.ps/news-4112-Israel_expresses_concern_as_protesters_continued.html |title=Israel Expresses Concern as Protesters Continued |publisher=[[Izz ad-Din al-Qassam Brigades]] |date=30 January 2011 |accessdate=31 January 2011}}</ref> The [[Associated Press]] reported that security officials anonymously expressed concern that the violence could threaten ties with Egypt, and spread to the [[Palestinian Authority]].<ref>http://www.washingtontimes.com/news/2011/jan/29/israel-watches-egypt-uprising-fear/</ref> The government was said to be pressuring the US to postpone a plan for Mubarak's departure so that it could prepare for any likely outcome.<ref name="bloombergreactions"/>
+
*: Foreign Minister [[Avigdor Lieberman]] told European diplomats at the [[Knesset]] that the root cause of the unrest was internal problems. "Whoever thinks that the Palestinian-Israeli conflict is part of the problems in the Middle East is trying to escape reality. [The] big picture of the Middle East shows that major points of contention stem from challenges and confrontations within Islamic society. The Arab world is becoming increasingly weakened. At the end of the day, it is clear to everyone, even to the [[Palestinian Authority]], that the greatest danger they are facing is not Zionism, but rather Hamas and Jihad."<ref>{{cite web|last=Lis |first=Jonathan |url=http://www.haaretz.com/news/diplomacy-defense/lieberman-mideast-uprisings-show-the-arab-world-is-weakening-1.341859 |title=Lieberman: Mideast uprisings show the Arab world is weakening â Haaretz Daily Newspaper | Israel News |publisher=Haaretz.com |date=7 November 2010 |accessdate=11 February 2011}}</ref> During the early days of the protests, the Foreign Ministry was receiving updates every few hours and Lieberman was in close contact with the Israeli ambassador to Egypt, Yitzhak Levanon.<ref>{{cite web|author=Ravid, Barak (with news agencies)|url=http://www.haaretz.com/news/diplomacy-defense/pm-netanyahu-israel-will-monitor-but-not-comment-on-egypt-protests-1.339895 |title=PM Netanyahu: Israel Will Monitor But Not Comment on Egypt Protests â The Foreign Ministry Is Conducting Status Updates on Egypt Every Couple of Hours and Foreign Minister Avigdor Lieberman Has Been Maintaining Close Contact with Israel's Ambassador to Egypt|work=[[Haaretz]] |date=29 January 2011 |accessdate=31 January 2011}}</ref> The Ministry was concerned over "substantial" changes in the regime.<ref name="israel evacuation">{{cite web|author=[[Staff writer]]|url=http://www.qassam.ps/news-4112-Israel_expresses_concern_as_protesters_continued.html |title=Israel Expresses Concern as Protesters Continued |publisher=[[Izz ad-Din al-Qassam Brigades]] |date=30 January 2011 |accessdate=31 January 2011}}</ref> The [[Associated Press]] reported that security officials anonymously expressed concern that the violence could threaten ties with Egypt, and spread to the [[Palestinian Authority]].<ref>{{cite web|last=Federman |first=Josef |url=http://www.washingtontimes.com/news/2011/jan/29/israel-watches-egypt-uprising-fear/ |title=Israel watches Egypt uprising with fear |publisher=Washington Times |date=2011-01-29 |accessdate=2011-04-27}}</ref> The government was said to be pressuring the US to postpone a plan for Mubarak's departure so that it could prepare for any likely outcome.<ref name="bloombergreactions"/>
** [[Binyamin Ben-Eliezer]], a [[Labor Party of Israel|Labor]] member of the Knesset (MK), said that "all we can do is express our" support for Mubarak and hope the riots pass quietly.<ref>{{cite news |author=[[Staff writer]]|title=Ben-Eliezer: All We Can Do Is Express Support for Mubarak |url=http://www.jpost.com/Headlines/Article.aspx?id=205362 |work=[[The Jerusalem Post]] |date=26 January 2011 |accessdate=31 January 2011}}</ref> He said Mubarak "had very tough things to say about the United States. [Mubarak] gave me a lesson in democracy and said: 'We see the democracy the United States spearheaded in Iran and with Hamas, in Gaza, and that's the fate of the Middle East. They may be talking about democracy but they don't know what they're talking about and the result will be extremism and radical Islam.'" According to him Mubarak realised "it was the end of the Mubarak era."<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.reuters.com/article/2011/02/11/us-egypt-israel-mubarak-idUSTRE71A64V20110211 |title=Mubarak slammed U.S. in phone call with Israeli lawmaker |publisher=Reuters |date=9 February 2009 |accessdate=13 February 2011}}</ref>
** [[Binyamin Ben-Eliezer]], a [[Labor Party of Israel|Labor]] member of the Knesset (MK), said that "all we can do is express our" support for Mubarak and hope the riots pass quietly.<ref>{{cite news |author=[[Staff writer]]|title=Ben-Eliezer: All We Can Do Is Express Support for Mubarak |url=http://www.jpost.com/Headlines/Article.aspx?id=205362 |work=[[The Jerusalem Post]] |date=26 January 2011 |accessdate=31 January 2011}}</ref> He said Mubarak "had very tough things to say about the United States. [Mubarak] gave me a lesson in democracy and said: 'We see the democracy the United States spearheaded in Iran and with Hamas, in Gaza, and that's the fate of the Middle East. They may be talking about democracy but they don't know what they're talking about and the result will be extremism and radical Islam.'" According to him Mubarak realised "it was the end of the Mubarak era."<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.reuters.com/article/2011/02/11/us-egypt-israel-mubarak-idUSTRE71A64V20110211 |title=Mubarak slammed U.S. in phone call with Israeli lawmaker |publisher=Reuters |date=9 February 2009 |accessdate=13 February 2011}}</ref>
** MK [[Ibrahim Sarsur]], who leads the [[United Arab List]], expressed "full support for the protesters in Egypt. The Arab [[police state]]s have given their peoples no other option but to take to the streets for a peopleâs revolution to topple the suppressing regimes and to free themselves from the control of dictators."<ref>{{cite news |author=Gedalyahu, Tzvi Ben|title=Israeli Arab MK Joins Iran and Jordan Islamists To Back Protests|url=http://www.israelnationalnews.com/News/News.aspx/142014|work=[[Arutz Sheva]]|date=30 January 2011 |accessdate=31 January 2011}}</ref>
** MK [[Ibrahim Sarsur]], who leads the [[United Arab List]], expressed "full support for the protesters in Egypt. The Arab [[police state]]s have given their peoples no other option but to take to the streets for a peopleâs revolution to topple the suppressing regimes and to free themselves from the control of dictators."<ref>{{cite news |author=Gedalyahu, Tzvi Ben|title=Israeli Arab MK Joins Iran and Jordan Islamists To Back Protests|url=http://www.israelnationalnews.com/News/News.aspx/142014|work=[[Arutz Sheva]]|date=30 January 2011 |accessdate=31 January 2011}}</ref>
Line 76: Line 76:
* {{flag|Colombia}} â [[President of Colombia|Colombian President]] [[Juan Manuel Santos]] asked Mubarak to ensure the situation returns to normal. He said that "[the Colombian people] moves along with the Egyptian people in search of their welfare, freedom and plain use of their human rights and trusts that Mubarak and his government would promote in a short term the return to calm and the strengthening of the democratic institutions." He told their embassy to be prepared to assist Colombian citizens in Egypt.<ref>{{clarify|date=February 2011|reason=headline in spanish. at minimum, needs english translation of spanish headline appended next to spanish headline}} [[Staff writer]] (31 January 2011). [http://www.eltiempo.com/politica/santos-pide-a-presidente-egipcio-fortalecer-instituciones-democraticas_8809619-4 "Santos pide a presidente egipcio fortalecer instituciones democrÃ¡ticas"] (in [[Spanish language|Spanish]]). ''[[Agence France-Presse]]'' (via ''[[El Tiempo (Colombia)|El Tiempo]]''). Retrieved 1 February 2011.</ref>
* {{flag|Colombia}} â [[President of Colombia|Colombian President]] [[Juan Manuel Santos]] asked Mubarak to ensure the situation returns to normal. He said that "[the Colombian people] moves along with the Egyptian people in search of their welfare, freedom and plain use of their human rights and trusts that Mubarak and his government would promote in a short term the return to calm and the strengthening of the democratic institutions." He told their embassy to be prepared to assist Colombian citizens in Egypt.<ref>{{clarify|date=February 2011|reason=headline in spanish. at minimum, needs english translation of spanish headline appended next to spanish headline}} [[Staff writer]] (31 January 2011). [http://www.eltiempo.com/politica/santos-pide-a-presidente-egipcio-fortalecer-instituciones-democraticas_8809619-4 "Santos pide a presidente egipcio fortalecer instituciones democrÃ¡ticas"] (in [[Spanish language|Spanish]]). ''[[Agence France-Presse]]'' (via ''[[El Tiempo (Colombia)|El Tiempo]]''). Retrieved 1 February 2011.</ref>
* {{flag|Cuba}} â [[Minister of Foreign Affairs (Cuba)|Minister of Foreign Affairs]] [[Bruno RodrÃ­guez Parrilla]] hoped for a positive outcome to the protests as one that "meets the interests of the Egyptian people and nation (''[[sic]]'')."<ref>(3 February 2011). [http://www.cubaminrex.cu/english/Actualidad/2011/enero/Cuba%20rejects.html Cuba Rejects U.S. Meddling in Egypt"]. Foreign Affairs of Cuba. Retrieved 5 February 2011.</ref>
* {{flag|Cuba}} â [[Minister of Foreign Affairs (Cuba)|Minister of Foreign Affairs]] [[Bruno RodrÃ­guez Parrilla]] hoped for a positive outcome to the protests as one that "meets the interests of the Egyptian people and nation (''[[sic]]'')."<ref>(3 February 2011). [http://www.cubaminrex.cu/english/Actualidad/2011/enero/Cuba%20rejects.html Cuba Rejects U.S. Meddling in Egypt"]. Foreign Affairs of Cuba. Retrieved 5 February 2011.</ref>
â
* {{flag|United States}} â [[President of the United States|US President]] [[Barack Obama]], noting that he had spoken with the Egyptian president, stated that his first concern is preventing injury or loss of life. He remarked, "What's needed right now are concrete steps that advance the rights of the Egyptian people...Ultimately the future of Egypt will be determined by the Egyptian people. The United States will always be a committed partner to that future, with the Egyptian government, and with the Egyptian people." He recalled that in his [[A New Beginning|speech in Cairo]] in June 2009 he had stated, "All governments must maintain power through consent, not coercion," and called upon the Egyptian government to restore its people's access to the internet. He called on all parties to refrain from violence in their efforts to bring about a solution.<ref name="Barack Obama">{{cite news|url=http://www.guardian.co.uk/news/blog/2011/jan/28/egypt-protests-live-updates|title=Egypt Protests Live Updates|work=[[The Guardian]]|date=28 January 2011|accessdate= 28 January 2011|location=London|first1=Matthew|last1=Weaver|first2=Haroon|last2=Siddique|first3=Richard|last3=Adams|first4=Tim|last4=Hill}}</ref> He said that the Egyptian protesters have "universal" rights, including the right to peaceful assembly and association, free speech, and âthe ability to determine their own destiny. [...] These are human rights and the United States will stand up for them everywhere."<ref>Johnston, Nicholas; Brower, Kate Andersen (29 January 2011). [http://www.bloomberg.com/news/28 January 2011/obama-says-mubarak-must-take-concrete-steps-to-deliver-pledge-on-reforms.html "Obama Tells Mubarak He Must Stick to Pledge of Democratic Reforms in Egypt"]. ''[[Bloomberg]]''. Retrieved 29 January 2011.</ref> White House spokesman [[Robert Gibbs]] expressed anger at the pace of change in Egypt, saying the transition should happen quickly, which he also said would determine US aid to the country.<ref>http://washingtonexaminer.com/politics/2011/02/us-angered-over-egypt-hopeful-over-yemen-jordan</ref> Gibbs posted a statement on [[Twitter]] expressing concern "about violence in Egypt", adding the "government must respect the rights of the Egyptian people & turn on social networking and the internet".<ref name="Twitter">{{cite web|url=http://twitter.com/PressSec/status/31026478648926208|title=Gibbs on Twitter|date=28 January 2011|accessdate= 28 January 2011}}</ref>
+
* {{flag|United States}} â [[President of the United States|US President]] [[Barack Obama]], noting that he had spoken with the Egyptian president, stated that his first concern is preventing injury or loss of life. He remarked, "What's needed right now are concrete steps that advance the rights of the Egyptian people...Ultimately the future of Egypt will be determined by the Egyptian people. The United States will always be a committed partner to that future, with the Egyptian government, and with the Egyptian people." He recalled that in his [[A New Beginning|speech in Cairo]] in June 2009 he had stated, "All governments must maintain power through consent, not coercion," and called upon the Egyptian government to restore its people's access to the internet. He called on all parties to refrain from violence in their efforts to bring about a solution.<ref name="Barack Obama">{{cite news|url=http://www.guardian.co.uk/news/blog/2011/jan/28/egypt-protests-live-updates|title=Egypt Protests Live Updates|work=[[The Guardian]]|date=28 January 2011|accessdate= 28 January 2011|location=London|first1=Matthew|last1=Weaver|first2=Haroon|last2=Siddique|first3=Richard|last3=Adams|first4=Tim|last4=Hill}}</ref> He said that the Egyptian protesters have "universal" rights, including the right to peaceful assembly and association, free speech, and âthe ability to determine their own destiny. [...] These are human rights and the United States will stand up for them everywhere."<ref>Johnston, Nicholas; Brower, Kate Andersen (29 January 2011). [http://www.bloomberg.com/news/28 January 2011/obama-says-mubarak-must-take-concrete-steps-to-deliver-pledge-on-reforms.html "Obama Tells Mubarak He Must Stick to Pledge of Democratic Reforms in Egypt"]. ''[[Bloomberg]]''. Retrieved 29 January 2011.</ref> White House spokesman [[Robert Gibbs]] expressed anger at the pace of change in Egypt, saying the transition should happen quickly, which he also said would determine US aid to the country.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://washingtonexaminer.com/politics/2011/02/us-angered-over-egypt-hopeful-over-yemen-jordan |title=US angered over Egypt, hopeful over Yemen, Jordan | The Associated Press | Politics |publisher=Washington Examiner |date=2011-02-02 |accessdate=2011-04-27}}</ref> Gibbs posted a statement on [[Twitter]] expressing concern "about violence in Egypt", adding the "government must respect the rights of the Egyptian people & turn on social networking and the internet".<ref name="Twitter">{{cite web|url=http://twitter.com/PressSec/status/31026478648926208|title=Gibbs on Twitter|date=28 January 2011|accessdate= 28 January 2011}}</ref>
*: [[Vice President of the United States|US Vice President]] [[Joseph Biden]] said Hosni Mubarak "has been an ally of ours in a number of things. And heâs been very responsible on, relative to geopolitical interest in the region, the Middle East peace efforts: the actions Egypt has taken relative to normalising relationship with Israel."<ref name="Joe Biden">{{cite news|last=Murphy|first=Dan|url=http://www.pbs.org/newshour/rundown/2011/01/exclusive-biden-discusses-unrest-in-egypt-keeping-us-competitive.html|title=Exclusive: Biden Discusses Unrest in Egypt, Keeping U.S. Competitive|publisher=[[Public Broadcasting Service]]|date=26 January 2011|accessdate= 28 January 2011}}</ref>
*: [[Vice President of the United States|US Vice President]] [[Joseph Biden]] said Hosni Mubarak "has been an ally of ours in a number of things. And heâs been very responsible on, relative to geopolitical interest in the region, the Middle East peace efforts: the actions Egypt has taken relative to normalising relationship with Israel."<ref name="Joe Biden">{{cite news|last=Murphy|first=Dan|url=http://www.pbs.org/newshour/rundown/2011/01/exclusive-biden-discusses-unrest-in-egypt-keeping-us-competitive.html|title=Exclusive: Biden Discusses Unrest in Egypt, Keeping U.S. Competitive|publisher=[[Public Broadcasting Service]]|date=26 January 2011|accessdate= 28 January 2011}}</ref>
*: [[United States Secretary of State|US Secretary of State]] [[Hillary Clinton]] said, "The Egyptian government has an important opportunity to be responsive to the aspirations of the Egyptian people, and pursue political, economic and social reforms that can improve their lives and help Egypt prosper."<ref name="Clinton">{{cite web|author=Awad, Marwa; Dziadoszurl, Alexander|url=http://www.publicbroadcasting.net/wrni/news.newsmain/article/0/0/1754229/.World./Egypt's.Mubarak.faces.unprecedented.protests|title=Egypt's Mubarak Faces Unprecedented Protests|publisher=''[[Reuters]]'' (via ''[[WRNI]]'')|date=25 January 2011|accessdate= 31 January 2011}}</ref> She told ''Al Jazeera'' that Mubarak has been an ally of the US in the past because he has maintained the [[EgyptâIsrael Peace Treaty|peace treaty]] with Israel in maintaining stability.<!--from tv-->{{Citation needed|date=January 2011}} She said the US supports an "orderly transition."<ref>{{cite web|author=[[Staff writer]]|url=http://english.aljazeera.net/news/middleeast/2011/01/2011130164532649572.html |title=''Al Jazeera'' Undeterred by Egypt Curb â Will Continue Its Comprehensive Coverage of Landmark Events There, Says Network Chief|work=[[Al Jazeera English]] |date=30 January 2011 |accessdate=31 January 2011}}</ref> On 8 March Clinton said Egypt's transition to democracy would be incomplete if women were not equal partners with men in creating the new society. She criticised the lack of women involved in efforts to draft a new constitution, saying in part, "The women in Egypt and [[Tunisia]] and other nations have just as much right as the men to remake their governments â to make them responsive, accountable, transparent."<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2011/03/08/clinton-women-middle-east-international-womens-day_n_832974.html|date=8 March 2011|accessdate=9 March 2011|agency=The Huffington Post|title=Clinton: Women Must Get Role In Middle East Transition}}</ref>
*: [[United States Secretary of State|US Secretary of State]] [[Hillary Clinton]] said, "The Egyptian government has an important opportunity to be responsive to the aspirations of the Egyptian people, and pursue political, economic and social reforms that can improve their lives and help Egypt prosper."<ref name="Clinton">{{cite web|author=Awad, Marwa; Dziadoszurl, Alexander|url=http://www.publicbroadcasting.net/wrni/news.newsmain/article/0/0/1754229/.World./Egypt's.Mubarak.faces.unprecedented.protests|title=Egypt's Mubarak Faces Unprecedented Protests|publisher=''[[Reuters]]'' (via ''[[WRNI]]'')|date=25 January 2011|accessdate= 31 January 2011}}</ref> She told ''Al Jazeera'' that Mubarak has been an ally of the US in the past because he has maintained the [[EgyptâIsrael Peace Treaty|peace treaty]] with Israel in maintaining stability.<!--from tv-->{{Citation needed|date=January 2011}} She said the US supports an "orderly transition."<ref>{{cite web|author=[[Staff writer]]|url=http://english.aljazeera.net/news/middleeast/2011/01/2011130164532649572.html |title=''Al Jazeera'' Undeterred by Egypt Curb â Will Continue Its Comprehensive Coverage of Landmark Events There, Says Network Chief|work=[[Al Jazeera English]] |date=30 January 2011 |accessdate=31 January 2011}}</ref> On 8 March Clinton said Egypt's transition to democracy would be incomplete if women were not equal partners with men in creating the new society. She criticised the lack of women involved in efforts to draft a new constitution, saying in part, "The women in Egypt and [[Tunisia]] and other nations have just as much right as the men to remake their governments â to make them responsive, accountable, transparent."<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2011/03/08/clinton-women-middle-east-international-womens-day_n_832974.html|date=8 March 2011|accessdate=9 March 2011|agency=The Huffington Post|title=Clinton: Women Must Get Role In Middle East Transition}}</ref>
